content: The Act titled "Natural Resource Management on Military Lands Act of 1994" amends the Sikes Act to promote wildlife conservation on military reservations. Integrated natural resource management plans are required for military installations. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, with exceptions if the Secretary deems it inappropriate. Conforming amendments are made to Title I to reflect this change. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, with exceptions if the Secretary deems it inappropriate. Conforming amendments are made to Title I to reflect this change, including replacing references to "cooperative plans" with "integrated natural resource management plans" throughout the Act. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States. This includes replacing references to "cooperative plans" with "integrated natural resource management plans" throughout the Act. Amendments also include adding wetland protection and restoration, consideration of conservation needs for all biological communities. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States. The plans must address fish and wildlife management, land management, forest management, and wildlife-oriented recreation, ensure consistency among activities, prevent a net loss in land capability for military missions, and allow sustained public use of natural resources. The Sikes Act is amended to require integrated natural resource management plans for military installations in the United States, ensuring public access to natural resources while maintaining consistency with the military mission. Public comment on these plans is also mandated. SEC. 4. REVIEW OF MILITARY INSTALLATIONS FOR INTEGRATED NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLANS. The Secretary of each military department must review all military installations in the United States to determine which ones require an integrated natural resource management plan. A report on these determinations must be submitted to the Secretary of Defense, who will then report to Congress within 12 months. The Secretary of Defense must prepare and implement integrated natural resource management plans for military installations within 2 years if deemed appropriate, as determined by a report submitted by the Secretary of each military department. The Secretary of Defense must complete negotiations with relevant agencies to update natural resource plans for military installations, allowing for public comments on proposed plans and changes. SEC. 5. ANNUAL REVIEWS AND REPORTS. Section 101 (16 U.S.C. 670a) is further amended by adding subsection (g) requiring the Secretary of Defense to review and report on the implementation of integrated natural resource management plans annually. The report must include the number of plans in effect, amount of money spent on conservation activities, and details on the Legacy Resource Management Program. The Secretary of Defense must review and report annually on integrated natural resource management plans, including details on the Legacy Resource Management Program. The Secretary of the Interior also submits a report on conservation expenditures in consultation with State agencies responsible for fish and wildlife management. The report on conservation activities conducted under integrated natural resource management plans involves committees from the House of Representatives and Senate. SEC. 6 amends Title I to allow the Secretary of Defense to enforce Federal laws on conservation of natural resources on military installations. SEC. 7 requires each military department to have trained personnel for natural resource management. SEC. 8 provides definitions. SEC. 8 amends Title I by inserting a new section 108 for definitions. SEC. 108 defines key terms such as military department, military installation, state fish and wildlife agency, and United States. SEC. 9 introduces the short title 'Sikes Act'. SEC. 10 amends cost-sharing basis in cooperative agreements. SEC. 11 repeals a section from a previous Act. SEC. 12 includes clerical amendments. Title I of the Act is amended to replace "military reservations" with "military installations" in various sections. Title I of the Act is amended to replace "military reservations" with "military installations" in various sections, including section 103 (16 U.S.C. 670c). SEC. 13. AUTHORIZATIONS OF APPROPRIATIONS. Amends sections related to programs on military installations and public lands by updating the years for authorizations of appropriations to 1994, 1995, 1996, and 1997.
